Lavrentieva 5 Novosibirsk 630090 Russia A NiMoP/Al2O3 catalyst deactivated at the industrial plant was subjected to oxidative regeneration and reactivation with water and an aqueous solution of citric acid. The catalyst was studied at all stages by XRD, UV–vis, Raman spectroscopy, FTIR spectroscopy, XPS and HRTEM methods. The catalyst samples after oxidative regeneration, treatment with water and rejuvenation with citric acid were tested in hydrotreatment of the model feedstock and straight-run gasoil. It was established that the regenerated catalyst contained phosphorus strongly bound to the support and soluble or insoluble Ni and Mo compounds. The catalyst after water treatment contained only insoluble Ni and Mo compounds and a phosphate monolayer, while treatment with citric acid resulted in the formation of citrate complex compounds. Ni and Mo compounds in the sulfide form, which were obtained from insoluble components, showed high activity in the target hydrotreating reactions. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Regeneration Reactivation Hydrotreating Phosphorus Citric acid 1 Introduction In the last decade, the regeneration process has been used for recovering the activity of deactivated hydrotreating catalysts. The process includes two sequential stages [1,2]: 1. The oxidative regeneration stage, which includes calcination in an air flow at 500–550ºС. The major amounts of carbon, sulfur and nitrogen are removed from the catalyst, while active metals (Co, Ni and Mo) turn into different oxygen-containing compounds [2–5]. 2. The rejuvenation stage, which comprises treatment of the calcined catalyst with aqueous solutions of organic complexing agents (mostly glycols and polybasic carboxylic acids) followed by maturation at < 100 оС and drying at a temperature that is lower than the decomposition temperature of carboxylic acids [1,2,4–7]. It is obvious that the composition and structure of compounds that have been formed in calcined catalysts after treatment by aqueous solution affect strongly the structure of the sulfide active component in regenerated and rejuvenated catalysts and their catalytic activity in hydrotreating. Besides the support (γ-Al2O3) and compounds of active metals (Co, Ni, Mo), fresh catalysts may contain oxides of B, Si and P [1–3]. Almost all these compounds are not volatile in the air at 500–550ºC because of the interaction with the support and remain in the composition of regenerated catalysts. The catalysts used in hydrotreating of diesel fuel do not contain a noticeable amount of contaminants, which are unremovable after calcination [3]. Regenerated catalysts usually contain slightly more Fe, Si, and Na oxides, as well as up to 1% of sulfur in the form of surface aluminum sulfates [1,2]. Thus, there are possible interactions between oxygen-containing compounds of Al, Co, Ni, Mo, B and Si present in the catalysts, as well as surface phosphates and aluminum sulfates, during the contact of regenerated catalysts with aqueous solutions. When ammonium heptamolybdate (NH4)6Mo7O24 × 4 H2O is applied from aqueous solutions to the γ-Al2O3, there is a transition of hydrated cations of Al3+ at pH 4–6. In this case, the quantitative formation of the Anderson heteropolyanion [Al(OH)6Mo6O18]3- occurs in a few hours [8,9]. It is known that ammonium salt of this heteropolyanion with the formula (NH4)3[AlMo6O24H6]× 7 H2O can be quantitatively obtained by the interaction of aqueous solutions of (NH4)6Mo7O24 × 4 H2O and Al3+ salts (aluminum sulfates [10,11] or aluminum nitrate [12]). Hence, the presence of surface sulfate groups in the composition of calcined catalysts should provide a transfer of soluble aluminum sulfate into solution and a rapid formation of the Anderson heteropolyanion [Al(OH)6Mo6O18]3- during the contact between catalyst and water. CoMoP/Al2O3 catalysts, which are synthesized by the use of ammonium heptamolybdate (NH4)6Mo7O24x4H2O and different heteropolyanions ([PMo9O34H4]5-; [P2Mo5O23]6-; [CoMo6O24H6]3- and its dimeric form [Co2Mo10O38H4]6-), have been studied in [13]. It is shown that the heteropolyanion [PCoMo11O40]7- forms along with the Anderson heteropolyanion [AlMo6O24H6]3- during the impregnation of the dried catalysts having a high phosphorus content (the molar ratio P/Mo ≥ 0.4) with an aqueous solution of triethylene glycol. The catalysts with a high content of [PCoMo11O40]7- are more active in the model reaction of toluene hydrogenation than the catalysts containing other heteropolyanions [13]. The formation of Mo citrate complex compounds [4,6,10], the interaction of maleic acid with Co leading to the formation of cobalt maleate, the redispersion of Mo as AlMo6 species [5], the redispersion of MoO3 and the decomposition of β-CoMoO4 under treatment with citric acid [7] were detected after treatment of the calcined catalysts with aqueous solutions of different carboxylic acids. In all cases, the hydrodesulfurization activity of the catalysts has been higher than the activity of the catalysts without treatment. Information on the regeneration of NiMo/Al2O3 catalysts is virtually absent in the literature. However, there are some works where the structure of calcined NiMoP catalysts is studied by extraction with water or other solvents. Lopez Agudo et al. [14] studied the behavior of NiMo/Al2O3 catalysts after water extraction and showed that solubilization of Mo increased in the presence of Ni due to the formation of heteropolycompounds. No clear structures have been obtained for water-soluble NiMo complexes. It was shown that treatment with water led to redispersion of active metals and increased the catalytic activity. Commercial NiMo/Al2O3 catalysts mostly contain 0.5–4.0 wt% of P, which contributes to the complexity of the system during the entire lifecycle of the catalyst, especially at regeneration and rejuvenation stages. Phosphorus is usually added to the catalyst together with active metals from an impregnation solution. The addition of phosphorus improves mostly the hydrodenitrogenation [15] and hydrodesulfurization catalytic activity [16] via increasing the sulfidation degree of a promotor [16] and changing the active component morphology [17] or the catalyst acidity [15]. Unfortunately, studies on regeneration of NiMoP catalysts are very scarce. However, several attempts have been made to study the extraction of such catalysts with different solvents, which could help to understand the behavior of the catalysts after treatment with different solutions. P. Atanasova et al. [18,19] performed single-step extraction of the calcined catalysts with water and observed that the amounts of phosphorus and aluminum washed off from the catalyst and passed into solution were relatively small and did not depend on the initial concentration of phosphorus in the catalyst. The largest amounts of removed molybdenum, nickel and aluminum during the water extraction were observed in the samples containing 2.7 and 4.2 wt% P2O5 (1.2–1.8 wt% P). The authors discussed the possible formation of heteropolycompounds in the solution; however, they did not provide information on the structure of these compounds. Extraction with water is only a part of the rejuvenation of NiMoP/Al2O3 catalysts. Currently, the rejuvenation of hydrotreating catalysts is carried out using an aqueous solution of citric acid. The high ability of citric acid to rejuvenate regenerated catalysts is due to its interaction with the surface oxide compounds of active metals (β-CoMoO4/CoO/MoO3/CoAl2O4) and formation of stable citrate complexes with a structure similar to that formed when citric acid is used to prepare impregnating solutions [4,20,21]. Nevertheless, it is not specified what amount of Co and Mo can be extracted with citric acid and how will change the surface structure of a catalyst during the interaction with water and citric acid. This issue is not clarified in the literature. Hence, there is an attempt to shed light on the behavior of a commercial NiMoP/Al2O3 catalyst, which deactivated during operation at an industrial diesel hydrotreating unit, during all steps of its regeneration. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of samples The commercial NiMoP/Al2O3 catalyst (14.8 wt% Mo, 3.0 wt% Ni and 2.8 wt% P) deactivated during operation for about 6 years at the industrial diesel hydrotreating unit. The amounts of carbon and sulfur in the fresh sulfide catalyst were 5.0 and 11.1 wt%, while their amounts in the deactivated catalyst were 6.5 and 10.3 wt%. The catalyst was subjected to oxidative regeneration on specialized industrial equipment at 550ºC (with a possible short-time increase in the temperature up to 600ºC) to remove carbon and sulfur compounds and convert Co and Mo to the oxide state. The oxidized form of the catalyst has an average surface area of 118 m2/g, a pore volume of 0.34 cm3/g and a pore diameter of 11.4 nm. Then the catalyst was sequentially treated with water and a citric acid solution. Finally, three catalyst samples were studied: 1) the regenerated catalyst that was calcined at 550оС (designated as NiMoP-R); 2) the NiMoP-R catalyst that was treated with water (designated as NiMoP-R-H2O); and 3) the NiMoP-R-H2O catalyst treated with an aqueous solution of citric acid (designated as NiMoP-R-H2O-Citr). 100 g of the NiMoP-R was immersed in 1500 ml of distilled water and stirred for 72 h at room temperature. The obtained aqueous solution with all compounds extracted from the NiMoP-R was separated from the NiMoP-R by filtration, drained into a porcelain cup and left to evaporate at room temperature until obtaining a loose precipitate of light gray-green color (designated as NiMoP-Sol). After washing, the catalyst sample was dried at 120оC for 2 h and calcined at 550оС for 2 h (designated as NiMoP-R-H2O). Calcination was carried out with the aim of converting all elements of the catalyst to the same form as in the regenerated catalyst in order to clearly understand which compounds leave and which remain in the catalyst. A 30 g sample of the NiMoP-R-H2O was impregnated with stirring 13 ml of an aqueous solution containing 2 g of citric acid at 60ºC for 1 h. After that, it was only dried at 120оС for 2 h to avoid decomposition of the chelate agent. The obtained sample is designated as NiMoP-R-H2O-Citr. Before elemental analysis, the NiMoP-R-H2O sample was additionally calcined at 550ºC for 2 h. The NiMoP-Sol sample was dried at room temperature in a desiccator over NaA zeolite. 2.2 Investigation techniques 2.2.1 Elemental analysis Elemental analysis was performed by the ICP-AES method on an OPTIMA 4300DV inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometer (PERKIN ELMER) with an operating wavelength range of 170–800 nm. 2.2.2 XRD X-ray diffraction analysis was carried out using an HCG 4-C diffractometer (Freiberger Prazisionsmechanik, Germany) equipped with a copper anode (CuKα) with a wavelength of 1.54 Å. 2.2.3 HRTEM After testing, the catalysts were investigated by HRTEM. After catalytic experiments in hydrotreatment of the real feedstock, the catalysts were washed with hexane prior to the analysis to remove the feedstock. Then, the samples were stored under hexane until analysis. Electron microscopy investigation was performed using a JEM-2200FS (JEOL Ltd., Japan) electron microscope operated at 200 kV with a lattice resolution of 0.1 nm for obtaining HRTEM images. Samples for HRTEM examination were prepared on a perforated carbon film mounted on a copper grid. The size of MoS2 particles and the average number of layers in the package were determined using four different fragments of the sample under study, with a total number of characterized particles being equal to 500. All characteristics were calculated as shown in SI1 and [22]. 2.2.4 XPS The X-ray photoelectron spectra of the catalysts were recorded using a SPECS spectrometer (Germany) with a PHOIBOS-150 hemispherical energy analyzer and Al Kα irradiation (hν = 1486.6 eV, 200 W). The binding energy scale was preliminarily calibrated using the peak positions of the Au4f7/2 (84.0 eV) and Cu2p3/2 (932.67 eV) core levels. The samples were supported using a conductive adhesive tape. The internal reference method was employed for the correct calibration of the photoelectron peaks. Al2р (Еb = 74.6 eV) and Al2s (Еb = 119.4 eV) lines were used for calibration. A low-energy electron gun (FG-15/40, SPECS) was used for the sample charge neutralization. 2.2.5 UV–vis DRS The UV-Vis diffuse reflectance spectra of NiMo catalysts were recorded using a UV-2501 PC Shimadzu spectrometer with an IRS-250A diffusion reflection attachment in the 11000–54000 cm−1 range. The measurements were performed in a 2 mm quartz cell in the air at room temperature using BaSO4 as a reference. The UV-Vis spectra were transformed into the Kubelka-Munk function (F(R)) calculated as F(R∞) = (1 – R∞)2/2 R∞, where R∞ is the experimentally measured reflectivity coefficient of the infinitely thick samples. 2.2.6 Raman spectroscopy The Raman spectra of NiMo catalysts were recorded in the frequency range of 3600–100 cm−1 with a resolution of 4 cm−1 by an RFS 100/S BRUKER Raman spectrometer (Germany). An Nd-YAG laser line centered at 1064 nm with a 100–450 mW power was used as the excitation source. 2.2.7 FTIR spectroscopy The FTIR spectra of solid samples were obtained in transmission mode in a KBr matrix using a Shimadzu FTIR 8300 IR Fourier spectrometer with a resolution of 4 cm−1 (the scanning was carried out 50 times). The solid complex species (4 mg) and catalyst powder (40 mg) were mixed with 800 mg of KBr and pressed into wafers. 2.3 Catalytic tests 2.3.1 Testing in model feedstock Sulfidation of the catalysts and their testing in hydrotreating of model feedstock were performed according to the procedures described in [4]. The catalysts were crushed to a 0.25–0.5 mm particle size and sulfided in an H2S (99% purity, admixtures – 1% of H2) flow of 500 h−1 at atmospheric pressure. Sulfidation was performed in two steps – 2 h at 200 °C and 2 h at 400 °C. Hydrodesulfurization of dibenzothiophene (HDS of DBT) was carried out using a fixed-bed microreactor featuring a high-pressure flow system. 0.150 g of the sulfide catalyst (0.25–0.5 mm) was diluted with 3 cm3 of the low-surface-area SiC (0.1–0.2 mm) and placed in the center of the reactor. The HDS activity was measured using the undecane solution containing 1.43 wt% DBT as the reactant (2500 ppm of sulfur) under the following conditions: pressure 3.5 MPa, liquid hour space velocity 40 h−1, H2/feedstock = 500 nl/l and temperature 280 °C. Then, the products were analyzed with a PerkinElmer Clarus 580 gas chromatograph. The DBT conversion was calculated using Eq. (1): (1) X DBT = C DBT 0 − C DBT C DBT 0 , where C0 DBT is the DBT content in the feedstock (wt%) and CDBT is the DBT content in the products (wt%). Since the content of metals in the NiMoP-R and NiMoP-R-H2O catalysts differed by a factor of almost two, the rate constant of DBT conversion was calculated not per catalyst weight but rather per the number of moles in the sum of active metals in the catalyst sample [23,24]. The rate constant of the pseudo-first-order DBT HDS was determined using Eqs. (2) and (3): (2) k HDSDBT = − F DBT M ln 1 − X DBT , (3) k HDS DBTg cat = − F DBT W ln 1 − X DBT where kHDSDBT is the pseudo-first-order reaction constant for DBT HDS (mol DBT mol metal−1 h−1); kHDS DBTg cat. – the pseudo-first-order reaction constant for DBT HDS (mol DBT g cat.−1 h−1); xDBT – the conversion of DBT; FDBT – the reactant flow (mol h−1); M – the sum of Mo and Ni moles in the catalyst loading; and W – the catalyst weight (g). 2.3.2 Testing in real feedstock It was necessary to provide the same weight hour space velocity for all the catalysts. For that, the bulk density values of catalysts were determined by ASTM D 4164–03. Then, 15 cm3 of a catalyst was taken. All the catalysts before sulfidation had different bulk densities (NiMoP-R – 0.853 g/cm3; NiMoP-R-H2O – 0.733 g/cm3; and NiMoP-R-H2O-Citr – 0.779 g/cm3) that corresponded to 12.8, 11.0 and 11.7 g of catalysts. Catalysts were in the form of granules with a trilobe cross-section. A sample portion equivalent to 15 cm3 of a catalyst was placed in the isothermal zone of the reactor and uniformly diluted with silicon carbide particles (with the size of 0.1–0.2 mm) at a volumetric ratio 1:2. A diluted catalyst bed was placed between two silicon carbide beds (the particle diameter of 3–4 mm) and the temperature in the catalyst bed was monitored with a five-point mini thermocouple installed vertically in the central part of the reactor. Sulfiding was performed with a dimethyl disulfide solution (20 g of DMDS per 1 liter of diesel fuel) in straight-run gasoil (SRGO) with 0.3 wt% of sulfur under the following conditions: a pressure of 3.5 MPa, a volumetric hydrogen/sulfiding mixture ratio of 300 nm3/m3 and a stepwise elevated temperature. The temperature regime comprises the following steps: drying in H2 flow (500 h−1) at 140ºC for 2 h, the onset of the feedstock mixture sulfiding at 140ºC, heating up to 240ºC for 4 h, holding at 240ºC for 8 h, heating up to 340ºC for 4 h, and holding at 340ºC for 8 h. This method is similar to the sulfiding techniques used at actual refinery plants. Catalysts were tested in hydrotreating of SRGO (0.41 wt% S; 120 ppm N; density 0.861 g/cm3; boiling temperature 207–380 °C (Gazpromneft-Omsk NPZ, Omsk, Russia)) in the same reactor unit directly after sulfiding. The process parameters were the following: P = 3.8 MPa, Н2/feed = 544 nm3/m3, LHSV = 2.5 h−1, T = 320; 340; and 360ºC. Catalysts were tested for 24 h at each temperature. The steady state was achieved after 12 h on stream at each temperature. The sulfur conversion during SRGO hydrotreating was calculated according to Eq. (4): (4) X S _ SRGO = C S _ SRGO 0 − C S _ SRGO C S _ SRGO 0 , where C0 S_SRGO is the S content in the feedstock (wt%) and CS_SRGO is the S content in the products (wt%). The rate constant of the pseudo-first-order reaction of sulfur in SRGO was determined using Eqs. (5) and (6): (5) k HDSSRGO = − F S _ SRGO M ln 1 − X S _ SRGO , (6) k HDSSRGOg cat . = − F S _ SRGO W ln 1 − X S _ SRGO , where kHDSSRGO is the pseudo-first-order reaction constant for sulfur in SRGO (mol S∙mol metal−1 h−1); kHDSSRGOg cat. – the pseudo-first-order reaction constant for sulfur in SRGO (mol S g cat.−1 h−1); XS_SRGO – the conversion of sulfur in SRGO; FS_SRGO – the reactant flow (mol h−1); M – the sum of Mo and Ni moles in the catalyst loading; and W – the catalyst weight (g). After sulfidation by DMDS solution in SRGO, different catalysts contain different amounts of condensed hydrocarbons and heteroatom compounds, which do not allow finding the precise weight of sulfide catalysts without deposits of C, H, S and N compounds. Since carbon deposits are localized in catalyst pores, the sulfidation procedure did not change the catalyst volume. Also, the amounts of Ni and Mo in the sample remain unchanged. Accordingly, it is possible to accurately determine the rate constant of sulfur in SRGO per the number of Mo + Ni moles in the catalyst, but it is impossible to accurately determine the rate constant of sulfur per gram of sulfided catalyst. Therefore, we calculated rate constants per 1 g of a fresh catalyst. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Investigation of NiMoP-R, NiMoP-R-H2O, NiMoP-R-H2O-Citr and NiMoP-Sol samples Elemental analysis data of the NiMoP-R, NiMoP-R-H2O and NiMoP-Sol samples are listed in Table 1. Data on the content of elements obtained from XPS spectra are listed in Table 2. The XPS spectra of all the catalysts (Figure SI2) contain peaks that are typical of Mo, P and Ni in the composition of unsulfided hydrotreating catalysts: the peaks of Mo3d5/2 with the binding energy of 232.4 ± 0.2 eV, which are characteristic of Mo(VI) in the oxygen environment; the peaks of P2p with the binding energy of 134.5 ± 0.2 eV, which are characteristic of PO4 3- anions on the Al2O3 surface; and the peaks of Ni2p3/2 with the binding energy of 856.5 ± 0.2 eV, which are characteristic of Ni2+ oxygen-containing compounds [18,25]. A comparison of elemental analysis and XPS data shows that almost half of molybdenum and nickel is removed after treatment of the NiMoP-R catalyst with water. According to analysis data of the NiMoP-Sol, a lot of sulfur and a small quantity of aluminum are also extracted. Almost all phosphorus is bound to the surface of Al2O3 and is not removed from the catalyst during treatment with water. Although the molar ratio P/Mo = 0.596 (Table 1) in the NiMoP-R catalyst is very high, there were no recovery of a considerable amount of phosphorus into the solution and no formation of phosphorus-containing heteropolycompounds after treatment of the NiMoP-R catalyst with water. The formation of water-insoluble compounds of phosphorus with aluminum oxide occurred at the calcination stage. The calcined catalyst does not contain heteropolycompounds, which are decomposed at temperatures higher than 500ºC. This is in agreement with the data reported in [13]. Sulfur is present in regenerated catalysts in the form of surface sulfates with a concentration similar to that obtained in [1,3,26,27]. It mostly passes into the solution under washing by water, obviously, in the form of sulfates anions. The presence of sulfate anions is visible in XPS spectra as a peak of S2p with a coupling energy of 169 eV (Figure SI2). Despite a large excess of water with respect to Mo and Ni and a very low concentration of Mo (5 g/l) and Ni (1 g/l) in the solution drained from the NiMoP-R sample, the NiMoP-R-H2O catalyst contained 7 wt% Mo and 1.5 wt% Ni. It is obvious that Ni and Mo are present in the NiMoP-R-H2O catalyst as water-insoluble compounds. Atomic ratios in the NiMoP-R and NiMoP-R-H2O catalysts being calculated from elemental analysis and XPS data are listed in Table 3. Atomic Ni/Mo ratios in the NiMoP-R and NiMoP-R-H2O catalysts determined from XPS and elemental analysis data are similar and typical of hydrotreating catalysts, which usually have the Ni/Mo ratio in the range of 0.25–0.40. Atomic Mo/P and Ni/P ratios obtained from elemental analysis data are about twice higher than those obtained by the XPS method. XPS is aimed at investigating surface structures since the average path length of emitted photoelectrons is 2–3 nm for most elements in the region of kinetic energies of photoelectrons used in this method. This determines a similar depth of analysis. The synthesis of hydrotreating catalysts usually includes impregnation of the Al2O3-based supports with aqueous solutions prepared from compounds of active metals and orthophosphoric acid [11–14,18,19,23–25]. In this case, Ni, Mo and P could localize over the support surface as individual ions or relatively large particles with sizes comparable to the XPS analysis depth (2–3 nm). A comparison of P/Al, Ni/Al and Mo/Al atomic ratios determined from elemental analysis and XPS data allows us to estimate quantitatively at an atomic level the presence of elements in the composition of bulk particles or in the dispersed form. Since the P/Al atomic ratio obtained from XPS is twice higher than that of elemental analysis data, it can be considered that all phosphorus is dispersed over the support surface and is not included into particles with a size greater than 2–3 nm. Then, if Ni and Mo were in the same dispersed form as phosphorus in NiMoP-R and NiMoP-R-H2O, the Ni/Al and Mo/Al ratios calculated from XPS data would be almost twice higher than those obtained from elemental analysis data. If Ni and Mo were included in the composition of particles, the size of which is several times larger than the depth of the XPS method, the Ni/Al and Mo/Al ratios obtained from the elemental analysis data should be greater than those of XPS data. This occurs because atoms located inside the particle at a depth of more than 2 – 3 nm are inaccessible to XPS analysis. Similar atomic Ni/Al and Mo/Al ratios obtained in our study from elemental and XPS analysis allow assuming that the NiMoP-R and NiMoP-R-H2O catalysts contain Ni and Mo in dispersed form and in the form of rather large particles. Based on the surface area value 118 m2/g and elemental analysis data (Table 1), the approximate surface concentrations of P, Mo and Ni are 4.8; 3.6 and 1.4 atoms per nm2, respectively. According to the data on sizes of phosphate anions in inorganic compounds [28], the radius of phosphate anion is in the range of 0.191–0.212 nm. Therefore, phosphate anion can occupy the area of 0.114–0.141 nm2. If the surface concentration of phosphate anions is 4.8 per nm2, they occupy 55–68% of the catalyst surface. Taking into account the required spacing between phosphate anions, the values of which should be comparable to the area occupied by phosphate anions, it can be considered that it is almost impossible to place any ions or particles over the catalyst surface without their contact with phosphate anions. The obtained results on the completeness of the catalyst surface coverage with phosphate anions are in good agreement with the data reported in [18]. Considering that the NiMoP-R-H2O sample contains water-insoluble Mo and Ni compounds, it is more likely that dispersed Mo and Ni ions and large Mo and Ni particles chemically interact with the support via phosphate bridges. XRD patterns of the NiMoP-R catalyst contain the peaks of γ-Al2O3, NiMoO4 and Al2(MoO4)3 ( Fig. 1). As follows from the comparison of XRD patterns of the NiMoP-R and NiMoP-R-H2O samples, there is a remarkable decrease in the intensity of NiMoO4 peaks after water treatment. These peaks are usually present in regenerated NiMo/Al2O3 hydrotreating catalysts [26]. The peaks of Al2(MoO4)3 are completely removed after the washing procedure. The XRD pattern of the NiMoP-Sol sample extracted from the solution is displayed in Fig. 2. It generally coincides with XRD patterns of the Anderson type polyoxomolybdate anions in (NH4)4H6NiMo6O24 ·4 H2O, [NH4]3Al(OH)6Mo6O18, and [Ni(H2O)4]2[Ni(OH)6Mo6O18]·4 H2O compounds described in [8,9,29–31] and also with XRD patterns of AlIIIMo6 and NiIIMo6 anions, the data of which are generalized in the review [32]. Therefore, it can be supposed that the NiMoP-Sol sample is a mixture of the compounds containing AlIIIMo6 and NiIIMo6 anions and various cations – H+, Ni2+, Al3+ and their hydrated forms. FTIR spectra of the NiMoP-R, NiMoP-R-H2O and NiMoP-Sol samples are displayed in Fig. 3. Positions of the bands in the spectra and their relation to the vibrations are listed in Table 4. The values for the bands in the spectrum of the NiMoP-R-H2O catalyst are similar to those in the spectrum of NiMoO4 (Table 4). However, the bands in the range of 970–800 cm−1 are slightly shifted and significantly broadened. The main component of the NiMoP-R-H2O catalyst relates to amorphous nickel molybdate or to the phase where nickel and molybdenum environments are similar to the molybdate structure. Apart from these bands, the spectra of the NiMoP-R and NiMoP-R-H2O catalysts contain additional bands at 960 and 980 cm−1. These vibrations correspond to MoO in α- and β-NiMoO4. The NiMoP-R and NiMoP-R-H2O catalysts have a peak at 1130 cm−1 corresponding to the superposition of the peaks from surface sulfates and phosphates [33,34]. The spectrum of the NiMoP-Sol sample, which was extracted by treatment of the NiMoP-R sample with water, contains the peaks of sulfate groups at 1070–1115 cm−1. In addition, there is a set of peaks from NiMo6 and AlMo6 heteropolyanions with the Anderson structure (Table 4). The spectrum is very typical of ХMo6 heteropolyanions and contains two main maxima in the range of 900 and 620 cm−1 described in [29,30,35–38]. The position of the peaks in the spectrum differs by several cm−1 from those reported in [24,29,30,35–37], since it is defined by numerous parameters, for example, by a cation type coordinated to heteropolyanion, an amount of coordinated water and so on. The Raman spectrum of the NiMoP-Sol sample is displayed in Fig. 4. The position of the main bands fits well the data reported in [8,9,12,29,41,42] for AlMo6 heteropolyanions and in [43] for NiMo6. A set of peaks in the range of 960–900 cm−1 from Mo-Oterm bonds, 580–540 cm−1 from symmetric vibrations of bridge Mo-O-Mo bonds, 380–330 cm−1 from MoO bending modes, and 220–210 cm−1 from Mo-O-Mo deformation vibrations are characteristic of AlMo6 and NiMo6. The exact positions of peaks in the Raman spectra of the NiMoP-Sol sample may differ from those described in the literature; this is caused by the type of cation in complex compounds or the distortion in symmetry of heteropolyanions. UV-Vis diffuse reflectance spectra of the NiMoP-R, NiMoP-R-H2O and NiMoP-Sol samples are displayed in Fig. 5. The spectra of the NiMoP-R and NiMoP-R-H2O catalysts are almost the same. The large absorption band at 200–400 nm can be assigned to the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (O2− → Mo6+) [44]. This region is often related to both the tetrahedral (Td) and octahedral (Oh) Mo6+. The region at 500–900 nm is attributed to the d-d transition of Ni2+. A small increase in intensity in the range of 670–800 nm relates to octahedrally distorted Ni2+ species, especially in NiMoO4 [44–46]. These bands of Mo and Ni are usually observed in calcined NiMo supported catalysts. There are no absorption bands characteristic of NiAl2O4 in the range of 580–670 nm [47]. Therefore, Ni is not present in both catalysts in a spinel position. The first difference between NiMoP-R and NiMoP-R-H2O catalysts is that the intensity of bands in the NiMoP-R-H2O spectrum is lower than in the NiMoP-R spectrum. Another one is observed in the range of 200–300 nm. UV–vis spectroscopy allows evaluation of the dispersion of supported molybdenum species because the electronic edge energy (Eg) of ligand-to-metal CT transitions in oxometallate species correlates with the number of neighboring molybdenum sites (NMo) in that species [48]. The correlation between edge energy and the number of next nearest neighbors of MoOx is shown in Figure SI3. The regenerated catalyst has a higher number of next nearest neighbors than NiMoP-R-H2O, which indicates a lower dispersion of Mo particles in the NiMoP-R catalyst. The spectrum of the NiMoP-Sol sample is more complicated. It resembles the spectrum of NiMo6 heteropolycompound of the Anderson type. A very intense peak at 200–400 nm is also assigned to Mo6+(Td) and Mo6+(Oh) in a polymolybdate-like structure containing Mo(Oh) ions [37–39,49]. The presence of the Mo (Td) band could be caused by the partial disorder of the heteropolyanion structure. The bands at 735, 667 nm and 395 nm correspond to octahedral Ni2+ ions in the heteropolyanion structure [38]. The band at 395 nm is overlapped with Mo(Oh), but is strong enough to detect it. Therefore, UV–vis data of the catalysts and NiMoP-Sol sample correlate with the XRD, FTIR and Raman data. To study the interaction of the NiMoP-R catalyst with water, FTIR spectra were recorded in the frustrated total internal reflection mode, i.e. the spectrum of the sample layer with a thickness of several microns was recorded. When there was a great amount of water, the solid sample was almost obscured by a non-transparent film of the solution (the spectra at 1 and 5 min in Fig. 6). Then, the water dried up (after an hour) and the spectrum was recorded from the solid phases. First, the only band from the molybdate ion MoO4 2- (895 cm−1) was observed. Then, the bands of heteropolycompounds (940, 920 and 640 cm−1) appeared. This indicates that nickel and molybdenum dissolve separately, further forming the Anderson heteropolycompound. After an hour, the spectra correspond to the superposition of the spectra of NiMoP-Sol (i.e. the Anderson heteropolycompound) and NiMoP-R-H2O catalysts. The peak at 1130 cm−1 from the surface sulfates and phosphates remains unchanged. After treatment of the NiMoP-R-H2O catalyst with citric acid, drastic changes are detected by FTIR spectroscopy ( Fig. 7). The band at 965 cm−1 from MoO in α- and β-NiMoO4 present in the NiMoP-R-H2O catalyst disappears after treatment with citric acid. The phosphate and sulfate vibrations at around 1130 cm−1 do not alter. The band at 878–880 cm−1 shifts to 850 cm−1 and the band at 710 shifts to 690 cm−1. These bands are characteristic of ν(Mo-O-Mo) and ν(MoO) vibrations in citrate molybdenum complex compounds [40,41]. The shifts in the bands’ position indicate the formation of new interactions between Mo and citrate ligand. There are two main bands in the range of 1700–1300 cm−1 with the maxima at 1618 and 1405 cm−1. The band at 1405 cm−1 is overlapped with the band at 1456 cm−1. All the mentioned bands correspond to νas(COO) and νs(COO) vibrations from citrate groups. These bands were assigned to carboxyl groups coordinated to Mo in [40,41]. No bands of non-deprotonated and unbound carboxyl groups were detected. Therefore, molybdenum mostly binds to citric acid in some complex compounds after treatment of the NiMoP-R-H2O catalyst with citric acid. The FTIR spectrum of the NiMoP-R-H2O-Citr catalyst contains a wide intense band at 720–660 cm−1 from Mo-O-Mo vibrations. The band has two distinct maxima at 712 and 690 cm−1 . The peak at 712 cm−1 refers to the vibrations of oxygen bridges in Mo-O-Mo in the composition of quadrangular [Mo4(C6H5O6)2O11]4- anions [50,51]. The peak at 690 cm−1 is attributed in [42,43] to the vibrations in νs(MoOMo) bridges in the composition of binuclear citrate anions [(MoO2)2O(Hcit)2]4-. This peak is absent in the FTIR spectra of mononuclear molybdenum citrate [MoO3(cit)]4- [52,53] and slightly differs from the prevailing peak at 710 ± 2 cm−1 [50,51] in the spectra of quadrangular anions [Mo4(C6H5O6)2O11]4-. The peak at 690 cm−1 has the highest intensity in the range of 720–660 cm−1 in the spectrum of the NiMoP-R-H2O-Citr sample. Then, binuclear molybdenum citrate anions [(MoO2)2O(Hcit)2]4- prevail in this sample. The total data set in the present Section allows us to make the following conclusions about the composition of each studied sample and the processes that occur during washing of the catalyst with water and its subsequent treatment with citric acid. 1. The calcined NiMoP-R catalyst contains: - S(VI) in the form of surface aluminum sulfates and possibly nickel sulfates;. - P (V) in the form of surface aluminum phosphates; the phosphorus concentration corresponds to a monolayer coverage of all the catalysts’ surface by phosphate anions PO4 3-;. - Mo(VI) in two forms – water-soluble and water-insoluble; α- and β-NiMoO4, Al2(MoO4)3 and MoO3 are predominant and may occur as the dispersed compounds and as the large particles detectable by XRD;. - Ni(II) in the form of NiMoO4 and possibly nickel sulfate. Since the catalyst surface is covered by phosphate anions, it is possible that some portions of molybdenum and nickel are bound to the support via phosphate bridges. 2. After treatment of the NiMoP-R sample with water, the following processes occur: - the major part of S(VI) transfers into solution, apparently in the form of soluble sulfates;. - most of P(V) remains in the catalyst and does not pass to the solution;. - about half of Mo(VI) in the catalyst transfers into solution, possibly in the form of МоO4 2- anions;. - about half of Ni(II) in the catalyst transfers into solution, possibly in the form of hydrated Ni2+ cations;. - a significant amount of aluminum passes to the solution, possibly in the form of hydrated Al3+ cations;. - МоO4 2- anions, hydrated Ni2+ cations and hydrated Al3+ cations become heteropolyanion complex compounds in the solution, which have an Anderson type structure (AlMo6 and NiMo6) and contain H+, Al3+ and Ni2+ as a cation. 3. The NiMoP-Sol catalyst is a mixture of the Anderson type polyoxomolybdate anions, for example, (NH4)4H6NiMo6O24 × 4 H2O, (NH4)3Al(OH)6Mo6O18, and [Ni(H2O)4]2[Ni(OH)6Mo6O18]× 4 H2O contaminated with impurities of aluminum and nickel compounds and sulfate anions. 4. The NiMoP-R-H2O catalyst treated with water has the following characteristics: - it has almost no sulfate anions;. - its surface is completely covered by phosphate anions PO4 3-, which prevents the formation of catalytically inactive surface spinels NiAl2O4; the absence of the spinels was confirmed by UV-Vis diffuse reflectance spectra (Fig. 5);. - it contains Mo(VI) and Ni(II) preferentially in the form of α- and β-NiMoO4, and MoO3, which could be in the dispersed form and in the form of large particles detected by XRD; it is possible that the major part of Mo(VI) and Ni(II) compounds is bound to the Al2O3 surface via phosphate bridges. 5. The NiMoP-R-H2O-Citr catalyst is characterized by the following: - its surface is entirely covered by phosphate anions PO4 3-;. - all molybdenum enters the composition of [(MoO2)2O(Hcit)2]4- and [Mo4(C6H5O6)2O11]4- anions to which the Ni2+ cations are possibly coordinated;. - Mo(VI) and Ni(II) compounds are shielded from Al2O3 by the layer of phosphate bridges. 3.2 Sulfide catalysts The preliminary liquid-phase sulfidation of catalysts by a solution of dimethyldisulfide in diesel fuel is widely used in industry. The sulfidation procedure is very similar to the one described in Section 2.3.2. During the sulfidation stage, DMDS is decomposed to H2S before it contacts with the catalyst particles. Catalysts after liquid-phase sulfidation usually have a smaller stacking number of the active component as compared to catalysts after gas-phase sulfidation [2]. The main difference is the temperature regimes used for sulfidation (200 and 400ºC for gas-phase sulfidation and 240 and 340ºC for liquid-phase sulfidation). However, liquid-phase sulfidation gives an idea of the state of the sulfide active component in catalysts under real industrial conditions. In the present work, we tested catalysts in hydrotreatment of the real feedstock only for three days. In this case, the catalyst was kept at the highest chosen temperature of 360ºC for only one day. No deactivation of catalysts was observed under these conditions. Then, it is unlikely that there is a change in the structure of NiMoS phase particles resulting in the formation of individual molybdenum disulfide and Ni3S2 particles, as it was described in [2]. Therefore, we suggest that the structure of the sulfide active component before and after the catalytic test differs insignificantly. That is why the catalysts sulfided in the liquid phase and unloaded from the reactor after catalytic tests in hydrotreatment of the real feedstock have been chosen for HRTEM investigations. The obtained values of the sulfur concentration and the S/Mo molar ratios are greater than 2 ( Table 5) and are close to the previously obtained values for CoMo catalysts with a high sulfidation degree [54]. This suggests that the NiMo catalysts studied in this work also have a high sulfidation degree. A comparison of characteristics of sulfide particles in the NiMoP-R, NiMoP-R-H2O and NiMoP-R-H2O-Citr catalysts (Table 5 and SI4) allows the following conclusions to be drawn: 1) The amount of visible sulfide layers of the active component particles per unit catalyst surface in the NiMoP-R catalyst is almost twice higher than that in the NiMoP-R-H2O and NiMoP-R-H2O-Citr catalysts (Table 5 and SI4). This is consistent with the elemental analysis data (Table 1), which show that the NiMoP-R catalyst contains a twofold higher amount of Ni and Mo than the NiMoP-R-H2O sample. 2) The NiMoS phase particles in the NiMoP-R catalyst have a much greater length and a higher stacking number compared to the NiMoP-R-H2O and NiMoP-R-H2O-Citr catalysts (Table 5 and SI4). This is consistent with the data of [51], which show that the catalyst sulfided after oxidative regeneration has higher length and stacking number than the catalyst treated with the citric acid solution before the sulfidation procedure. The NiMoP-R-H2O and NiMoP-R-H2O-Citr catalysts have a similar morphology of the sulfide active component particles (Table 5 and SI4). The literature data concerning the influence of citric acid and phosphorus on the slab length and the stacking number of active component particles in NiMo catalysts are very controversial [55–58]. This is caused by differences in both the catalyst preparation methods and the properties of the supports. In our case, the difference between sulfide particles in the NiMoP-R-H2O and NiMoP-R-H2O-Citr catalysts is very small since all the supports’ surface is covered by phosphate anions PO4 3-. Obviously, molybdenum and nickel compounds shielded from possible interaction with Al2O3 by the phosphate layer are being sulfided in a similar way irrespective of the presence of citrate ligand. Thus, a similar catalytic behavior can be expected for the NiMoP-R-H2O and NiMoP-R-H2O-Citr catalysts. 3) The most notable difference between the NiMoP-R-H2O and NiMoP-R-H2O-Citr catalysts is observed in the average number of layers per 1000 nm2. Obviously, treatment of the oxygen-containing compounds of nickel and molybdenum in the NiMoP-R-H2O catalyst with an aqueous solution of citric acid results in their redispersion, as described in [51], and an increase in the average number of layers per 1000 nm2 from 26 to 33, which should enhance the catalytic activity of the NiMoP-R-H2O-Citr catalyst. 3.3 Catalytic activity 3.3.1 The results of testing in hydrotreating of model feedstock DBT is transformed under hydrotreating conditions in hydrogenation and direct hydrodesulfurization reaction pathways. The main reaction products are phenylcyclohexane (PhCh) and biphenyl (BPh) ( Table 6). An increase in the process temperature improves the DBT conversion for all the catalysts. The NiMoP-R-H2O and NiMoP-R-H2O-Citr catalysts have a lower hydrodesulfurization activity than the NiMoP-R catalyst (if calculations are made per 1 g of a sample), which is reasonable due to the lower content of metals. However, HDS activities of the NiMoP-R-H2O and NiMoP-R-H2O-Citr catalysts increase stronger with the temperature rise as compared to the NiMoP-R sample. When the process temperature is 270ºC, the HDS activity of the NiMoP-R catalyst is 23% higher than that of the NiMoP-R-H2O and NiMoP-R-H2O-Citr catalysts. This difference becomes only 18% at the process temperature of 280ºC. On the other hand, the constants of the DBT conversion normalized to mole of the total metals content calculated for the NiMoP-R-H2O and NiMoP-R-H2O-Citr samples are similar. Moreover, they are almost 1.6 times higher than those for the NiMoP-R sample at both hydrotreating temperatures, 270ºC and 280ºC. The main product of the DBT transformation is BPh, since its weight yield is more than twice higher than the yield of PhCh. Therefore, the direct desulfurization route prevails under the chosen conditions. For the NiMoP-R and NiMoP-R-H2O catalysts, the yields of BPh and PhCh increase with the temperature, while their ratio in the products changes only slightly. It is noted that the BPh/PhCh ratio increases in the following order: NiMoP-R < NiMoP-R-H2O ≤ NiMoP-R-H2O-Citr. Then, treatment of the catalysts with water or citric acid increases the contribution of the direct desulfurization route. This result fits well with our data in Table 5 and the data of [59,60], which show that a higher stacking number of the active component results in a higher portion of hydrogenated compounds in the reaction products for the case of HDS of DBT or 4,6-DMDBT with supported NiMo catalysts. In our case, the NiMoP-R catalyst has a higher stacking number and a greater slab length than the NiMoP-R-H2O and NiMoP-R-H2O-Citr catalysts, by 10% and 17%, respectively. Thus, NiMoP-R catalyzes the hydrodesulfurization reaction preferentially via the hydrogenation route, while other catalysts provide the direct desulfurization route. Therefore, the results of the model feedstock hydrotreating show that the NiMoP-R-H2O and NiMoP-R-H2O-Citr catalysts have a much higher catalytic activity normalized to mole of nickel and molybdenum as compared to the NiMoP-R catalyst. The NiMoP-R-H2O and NiMoP-R-H2O-Citr catalysts, which contain a high amount of monolayered short sulfide particles, are also characterized by the prevailing conversion of DBT via the direct desulfurization route. 3.3.2 The results of testing in hydrotreating of real feedstock The results of catalysts testing in hydrotreating of diesel feedstock are presented in Fig. 8 and Tables 7 and 8. Fig. 8 shows the residual sulfur and nitrogen contents achieved during hydrotreating at equal volume loadings of the catalysts (15 cm3). It follows that the NiMoP-R catalyst has intermediate hydrodesulfurization activity between the NiMoP-R-H2O and NiMoP-R-H2O-Citr catalysts per unit volume of a catalyst at all the studied temperatures (320, 340 and 360ºC). The highest residual sulfur content at all the temperatures was observed for the NiMoP-R-H2O catalyst. The behavior of the catalysts in hydrodenitrogenation reactions depending on the process temperature is more complicated. The NiMoP-R-H2O-Citr catalyst has the highest hydrodenitrogenation activity. In spite of the twofold difference in the concentration of active metals, the NiMoP-R and NiMoP-R-H2O catalysts have a similar activity. The NiMoP-R-H2O-Citr catalyst has the maximum sulfur conversion in hydrodesulfurization of SRGO and the maximum conversion rate constant of sulfur compounds at all the studied temperatures (Tables 7 and 8). It is an expected result since there are many published papers illustrating different positive effects exerted by citric acid on the catalytic properties of hydrotreating catalysts during their preparation and regeneration. In our case, the NiMoP-R-H2O-Citr catalyst has the highest dispersion of sulfide active particles and the highest average number of layers per 1000 nm2 among other samples. Obviously, the best morphology of sulfide active particles in the NiMoP-R-H2O-Citr catalyst, which leads to a higher catalytic activity, is caused by a combination of two factors. The first is the shielding of nickel and molybdenum from undesirable interaction with the Al2O3 surface by a phosphate layer, as it follows from the present work and [51]. The second factor is the decrease in the interaction of active metals with the support due to the presence of a carbon layer, which forms from citrate ligands at drying and sulfidation stages, as it was earlier shown by us and other authors [22,61–64]. In the present work, there was no task to prepare a catalyst with the highest hydrodesulfurization activity per catalyst volume; the aim was to reveal the oxide precursor of sulfide active particles in regenerated catalysts. This allows the formation of the most active sulfide component. To this end, it can be assumed that the NiMoP-R catalyst contains two types of sulfide particles. Type I. The sulfide particles formed from water-soluble Ni and Mo compounds, which can be washed off from the catalyst. These compounds can convert heteropolycompounds with the Anderson structure. Type II. The sulfide particles formed from Ni and Mo compounds, which are not washed off from the catalyst with water. The same particles are present in the NiMoP-R-H2O catalyst and possibly have similar catalytic properties. Further, it can be assumed that the conversion of sulfur compounds on the sulfide particles of Type II in the composition of NiMoP-R catalyst is similar to that on the sulfide particles of Type II in the NiMoP-R-H2O catalyst. Then, the conversion of sulfur compounds on the particles of Type I in the NiMoP-R catalyst is equal to the difference between conversions of sulfur compounds by the NiMoP-R and NiMoP-R-H2O catalysts. This difference is shown in Table 7 in column C( NiMoP-R-H2O ). If we further evaluate the rate constant of sulfur conversion over sulfide particles of Type I in the NiMoP-R catalyst (Table 8, the column C( NiMoP-R - NiMoP-R-H2O), we can assume that the rate constant for the sulfide particles of Type I is two orders of magnitude lower than for the Type II particles. This ratio is observed for calculations of the desulfurization rate constant per mole of metals and per gram of a catalyst. The above-mentioned assumptions are not completely correct. However, they still make it possible to qualitatively evaluate the catalytic properties of sulfide active components in the NiMoP-R catalyst, which were obtained from different precursors. The results obtained show that Ni and Mo compounds, which can be easily removed with water from the catalyst, form the sulfide active component that is low active in hydrodesulfurization. 4 Conclusions The composition of the commercial NiMoP/Al2O3 catalyst, which was previously deactivated at the industrial diesel hydrotreating unit and further subjected to oxidative regeneration, was studied. The regenerated catalyst contains surface sulfate and phosphate anions as well as Ni and Mo compounds. Ni and Mo compounds could be divided into two groups: 1) compounds that can be easily washed off from the catalyst surface; and 2) compounds that are almost insoluble in water. Washing of the regenerated catalyst with water results in the following processes. Most of the sulfate anions are converted to the soluble state and about half of Mo and Ni is removed from the catalyst. Phosphate anions are virtually not removed with water from the catalyst surface. Aluminum, nickel and molybdenum compounds, which have been transferred to the solution, turn to heteropolycompounds with the Anderson type structure (AlMo6 and NiMo6) and H+, Al3+ and Ni2+ cations. After treatment with water, the catalyst contains insoluble Ni and Mo compounds bound to the surface of the support. The concentration of phosphorus in the catalyst corresponds to a monolayer coverage of the support surface by phosphate anions PO4 3-. This prevents the formation of undesirable catalytically inactive surface spinels NiAl2O4. Further treatment of the catalyst with an aqueous solution of citric acid leads to the conversion of active metals to citrate complexes comprising [(MoO2)2O(Hcit)2]4- and [Mo4(C6H5O6)2O11]4- anions and Ni2+ cations. After sulfidation, such citrate compounds have a very high catalytic activity in hydrodesulfurization and hydrodenitrogenation reactions, which fits well with the literature data. It is of great interest that the sulfided insoluble Ni and Mo compounds in the catalyst treated with water, which are shielded from the support surface by phosphate anions, have also a high desulfurization activity. Finally, the sulfide compounds formed from Ni and Mo compounds, which are easily washed off with water from the catalyst surface and form heteropolycompounds with the Anderson type structure (AlMo6 and NiMo6) in an aqueous solution, are the least active components of the regenerated NiMoP/Al2O3 catalyst. coredata.dc:description: A NiMoP/Al2O3 catalyst deactivated at the industrial plant was subjected to oxidative regeneration and reactivation with water and an aqueous solution of citric acid. The catalyst was studied at all stages by XRD, UV–vis, Raman spectroscopy, FTIR spectroscopy, XPS and HRTEM methods. The catalyst samples after oxidative regeneration, treatment with water and rejuvenation with citric acid were tested in hydrotreatment of the model feedstock and straight-run gasoil. It was established that the regenerated catalyst contained phosphorus strongly bound to the support and soluble or insoluble Ni and Mo compounds. The catalyst after water treatment contained only insoluble Ni and Mo compounds and a phosphate monolayer, while treatment with citric acid resulted in the formation of citrate complex compounds. Ni and Mo compounds in the sulfide form, which were obtained from insoluble components, showed high activity in the target hydrotreating reactions.
coredata.dc:title: Investigation of the regeneration of NiMoP/Al2O3 hydrotreating catalysts
